qas.question: What did John Maynard Keynes want to separate?
What concept did Milton Friedman propose after World War II?
How did monaterism aim to control the economy?

answers.text: using the supply and demand of money

qas.question: In the 1970s, what did monaterism turn into?
How did supply-side economics try to increase the amount of money in the market?

context: In the 1920s, John Maynard Keynes prompted a division between <a0_0>microeconomics and macroeconomics<a0_0/>. Under Keynesian economics macroeconomic trends can overwhelm economic choices made by individuals. Governments should promote aggregate demand for goods as a means to encourage economic expansion. Following World War II, Milton Friedman created the concept of <a1_0>monetarism<a1_0/>. Monetarism focuses on <a2_0>using the supply and demand of money<a2_0/> as a method for controlling economic activity. In the 1970s, monetarism has adapted into <a3_0>supply-side economics<a3_0/> which advocates <a4_0>reducing taxes<a4_0/> as a means to increase the amount of money available for economic expansion.
